title: 110_s3024
content: The Act may be cited as the "Eurasia Foundation Act" and includes findings and purposes. The Eurasia Foundation Act establishes a private, nonprofit corporation in the District of Columbia called the Eurasia Foundation, which receives financial support from the United States Government. This support aims to further strengthen cooperation with Eurasian countries. The Eurasia Foundation, a private nonprofit corporation in DC, receives US Government financial support to promote civil society, private enterprise, and sound public administration in Eurasian countries. Its purposes include fostering national development, social change, economic growth, and international relationships in line with US interests in Eurasia. The Eurasia Foundation conducts programs in response to initiatives in Eurasian countries to quickly and flexibly meet new opportunities. The Eurasia Foundation conducts programs in response to initiatives in Eurasian countries to quickly and flexibly meet new opportunities. Grants are provided to the Foundation. The Secretary of State awards annual grants to the Foundation for specific purposes outlined in section 2(b), with requirements for fund appropriation and compliance with grant agreements. The Foundation established by this Act is not considered a government agency, and its members are not considered government officials. Congress oversees the Foundation and its grantees, and the Foundation can receive funding from non-government sources. Congress believes that the Foundation can make significant contributions with the authorized funding levels. The Foundation should seek competitive grants to supplement appropriations from the United States Government, with at least 20 percent of funding from non-government sources to ensure strong performance. The Foundation must be eligible for grants to supplement government funding and ensure strong performance. The Foundation may only fund programs consistent with its purposes. Officers or employees of the US government serving on the Board of Directors may not receive compensation. The Foundation is prohibited from issuing stock or paying dividends, and assets cannot benefit Board members or employees except for reasonable expenses. The Foundation's accounts are audited annually in accordance with US Code. The audit report includes details on assets, liabilities, income, expenses, and fund allocation. The Foundation's financial transactions are audited annually by the Government Accountability Office in accordance with prescribed principles. The Comptroller General submits a report to the President and congressional committees containing necessary comments and information. The Foundation must ensure recipients of financial assistance maintain necessary records to disclose the amount and use of funds. The Comptroller General provides recommendations and financial information to congressional committees. The Foundation must ensure recipients maintain records of financial assistance for auditing purposes. The Foundation, authorized representatives, and the Comptroller General have access to recipient records for audit and examination. Annual reports and testimony related to the report are required. The Foundation must submit an annual report by June 30 each year to the President and congressional committees, detailing its operations, activities, financial condition, accomplishments, and addressing any misuse of funds. The Foundation must submit an annual report to the President and congressional committees, including recommendations determined to be appropriate. Board members and officers must be available to testify on the report, audits, or other matters requested by committees. A member of the Board who serves as a member of a grantee's board or officer cannot receive compensation for services provided. Board members serving as a grantee's board member cannot receive compensation but can be reimbursed for expenses related to their duties. SEC. 5. AGREEMENT BETWEEN FOUNDATION AND SUCCESSOR OR RELATED ENTITY TO THE U.S. RUSSIA INVESTMENT FUND. The Foundation and any successor or related entity to the U.S. Russia Investment Fund must enter into a memorandum of understanding to coordinate activities and prevent duplication. This agreement must be finalized within 90 days of the enactment of the Act or establishment of the successor entity. The Foundation and any successor entity must submit a memorandum of understanding to the Secretary of State and congressional committees within 30 days of its establishment. The successor entity is defined as any organization receiving funds from the U.S. Russia Investment Fund. The remaining funds of the U.S. Russia Investment Fund were liquidated upon its closure. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to the Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations and the House of Representatives' Committee on Foreign Affairs. The term "countries of Eurasia" includes Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the Kyrgyz Republic, Moldova, the Russian Federation, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, and Uzbekistan. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $15,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2009 and additional funds for fiscal year 2010. Appropriated amounts remain available for 2 years after the fiscal year.
